div.p: I am overwhelmed by such waves of business, my Bullinger, that I am forced to be briefer than I would like. Therefore, I briefly respond to your letters, and in order.
I will gladly do a favor for Burcher, both for his sake and also for yours. If only Burcher's character matched Burcher's! But this is for you alone.

Gwalther has disappointed my expectations, writing nothing to me now. I was in Abel's house when a bundle of letters was brought: yet at that time I received none except yours and Julius's letters; which I was very surprised about. Regarding the state of the kingdom in religion, consider this.

Many pious people are pleased with everything, but a few things still displease me: but I hope for better. In a few months, the Scots have made more progress in the true religion than we have in many years.

Among the Scots, the French, and us, (with the town of Leith surrendered) peace has been established: Abel has written the terms to you. Calais has not been recovered by us; indeed, nothing of the sort has been attempted.

Greet in my name your excellent wife, sons, daughters, sons-in-law, and all learned men and my friends. I wish all the best for your city, and indeed for the entire dominion of the Zurichers. My wife has instructed me to send many greetings to all of you.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger.
